Problem solving of the orbits, kinematics, and dynamics of astronomical systems, structure and evolution of stars and galaxies. Pre- or coreq: MATH 252; PHYS 252 or equivalents.

CourseID: PHYS 152. Physics of Sound and Music. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to the wave nature of sound; hearing; musical instruments and scales; auditorium acoustics; and the transmission, storage, and reproduction of sound.

CourseID: PHYS 155. Physics behind the Internet. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: How discoveries in 20th-century physics mesh to drive modern telecommunications. Topics include electron mobility in matter, the development of transistors and semiconductors, lasers, and optical fibers.
Surveys several major revolutions in our views of the natural and technological world, focusing on scientific concepts and methodological aspects. For non science majors. Multi listed with GEOL 156M.

CourseID: PHYS 161. Physics of Energy and Environment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Practical study of energy generation and environmental impact, including energy fundamentals, fossil fuel use, global warming, nuclear energy, and energy conservation.

CourseID: PHYS 171. The Physics of Life. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Explores how physical laws guide the structure, function, and behavior of living organisms, and examines the physical properties of biological materials. Topics span micro s crop ic and macroscopic scales.

CourseID: PHYS 181. Quantum Mechanics for Everyone. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to quantum mechanics, a set of sometimes counter intuitive scientific principals describing atoms and light, along with the modern technologies it makes possible.

Practical exploration of the principles studied in general-physics lecture. Measurement and analysis methods applied to experiments in mechanics, waves, sound, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Sequence. Pre- or coreq: PHYS 201.

Practical exploration of the principles studied in general-physics lecture. Measurement and analysis methods applied to experiments in mechanics, waves, sound, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Pre- or coreq: PHYS 202.

Practical exploration of the principles studied in general-physics lecture. Measurement and analysis methods applied to experiments in mechanics, waves, sound, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Pre- or coreq: PHYS 203.

CourseID: PHYS 251. Foundations of Physics I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Newtonian mechanics; units and vectors; one-dimensional motion; Newton’s laws; work and energy; momentum and collisions. Sequence. Coreq: MATH 251; Prereq MATH 112 or equivalent.

CourseID: PHYS 253. Foundations of Physics I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Electricity and magnetism; charge and electric field; electric potential; circuits; magnetic field; inductance. Prereq: PHYS 252; coreq: MATH 253 or equivalent.

CourseID: PHYS 290. Foundations of Physics Laboratory. 1 Credit.
Descriptions: Repeatable. Introduction to laboratory measurements, reports, instrumentation, and experimental techniques. Repeatable twice for maximum of 3 credits. Coreq: PHYS 251, 252 or 253.

CourseID: PHYS 301. Physicists' View of Nature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Illustrates physics concepts through the work of prominent physicists. The classical view--mechanics, electrical science, thermal physics. Prereq: WR 122 or equivalent.

CourseID: PHYS 351. Foundations of Physics II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to relativity and quantum physics with applications to atomic, solid-state, nuclear, and astro-particle systems Prereq: MATH 253, PHYS 253; coreq: MATH 256 or 281.

Physical principles governing biological systems. Topics include molecular machines, DNA and other macromolecules, signaling and information transfer, en tropic forces, and physical mechanisms of self-organization. Prereq: PHYS 351 or 353.

CourseID: PHYS 391. Physics Experimentation Data Analysis Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Practical aspects of physics experimentation, including data acquisition, statistical analysis, and introduction to scientific programming, and use of Fourier methods for data analysis.

CourseID: PHYS 411. Mechanics, Electricity, and Magnetism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics, conservation laws, small oscillations, planetary motion, systems of particles. Electromagnetic phenomena. Series. Only non majors may earn graduate credit. Prereq: MATH 282.

CourseID: PHYS 412. Mechanics, Electricity, and Magnetism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics, conservation laws, small oscillations, planetary motion, systems of particles. Electromagnetic phenomena. Series. Prereq: MATH 281.

CourseID: PHYS 413. Mechanics, Electricity, and Magnetism. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Fundamental principles of Newtonian mechanics, conservation laws, small oscillations, planetary motion, systems of particles. Electromagnetic phenomena. Series. Prereq: PHYS 412.

Planck's and de Broglie's postulates, the uncertainty principle, Bohr's model of the atom, the Schroedinger equation in one dimension, the harmonic oscillator, the hydrogen atom, molecules and solids, nuclei and elementary particles. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 413.

Planck's and de Broglie's postulates, the uncertainty principle, Bohr's model of the atom, the Schroedinger equation in one dimension, the harmonic oscillator, the hydrogen atom, molecules and solids, nuclei and elementary particles. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 414.

CourseID: PHYS 421M. Partial Differential Equations: Fourier Analysis I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to PDEs with a view towards applications in physics. Wave and heat equations, classical Fourier series on the circle, Bessel and Legendre series. Multi listed with MATH 421M. Prereq: MATH 253; one from MATH 256, MATH 281.
Study of electromagnetic waves. Topics include Maxwell's equations, wave equation, plane waves, guided waves, antennas, and other related phenomena. Prereq: PHYS 413.
Special topics in modern applied optics such as Fourier optics, coherence theory, resonators and lasers, holography, and image processing. Prereq: PHYS 424.

Passive and active discrete components and circuits. General circuit concepts and theorems. Equivalent circuits and black box models. Integrated circuit operational amplifiers. Prereq: PHYS 203 or equivalent; knowledge of complex numbers; MATH
Digital electronics including digital logic, measurement, signal processing and control. Introduction to computer interfacing. Prereq: PHYS 203 or equivalent; MATH 253.
Applies statistics to practical data analysis, data-based decision making, model building, and the design of experiments. Emphasizes factorial designs.

For physics and other science majors, Physics Projects entails construction and use of apparatus, interfaces and computers to perform technically-sophisticated experiments, analyze and communicate results. Prereq: PHYS 391 or PHYS 399.

For physics and other science majors, Physics Projects entails construction and use of apparatus, interfaces and computers to perform technically-sophisticated experiments, analyze and communicate results. Prereq: PHYS 491.

For physics and other science majors, Physics Projects entails construction and use of apparatus, interfaces and computers to perform technically-sophisticated experiments, analyze and communicate results. Prereq: PHYS 492.

CourseID: PHYS 517. Topics in Quantum Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Perturbation theory, variation al principle, time-dependent perturbation theory, elementary scattering theory. Only non majors may earn graduate credit. Prereq: PHYS 415/515.

CourseID: PHYS 521M. Partial Differential Equations: Fourier Analysis I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to PDEs with a view towards applications in physics. Wave and heat equations, classical Fourier series on the circle, Bessel and Legendre series. Multi listed with MATH 521M.
Applies statistics to practical data analysis, data-based decision making, model building, and the design of experiments. Emphasizes factorial designs.
Thermodynamics, statistical mechanics, kinetic theory, application to gases, liquids, solids, atoms, molecules, and the structure of matter. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 613.

Microscopic form of Maxwell's equations, derivation and solution of the wave equation, Lorentz covariant formulation, motion of charges in given fields, propagation and diffraction, radiation by given sources, coupled motion of sources and fields, the electromagnetic field in dense media.

Microscopic form of Maxwell's equations, derivation and solution of the wave equation, Lorentz covariant formulation, motion of charges in given fields, propagation and diffraction, radiation by given sources, coupled motion of sources and fields, the electromagnetic field in dense media. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 622.

CourseID: PHYS 626. Physical Optics with Labs. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Fundamentals of applied geometric and wave optics theory, reinforced through homework assignments, and explored in experiments conducted with lasers and optical components. Sequence with PHYS 627, PHYS

CourseID: PHYS 627. Optical Materials and Devices. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Principles of quantum mechanics and solid-state physics relating to material properties of op to electronic devices with corresponding laboratories teaching how to operate and characterize these devices. Sequence with PHYS 626, PHYS 628. Prereq: PHYS 626 with B- or better grade.

CourseID: PHYS 628. Laser and Nonlinear Optics with Optic Studio. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to the nature of laser and nonlinear optics and the practical systems that utilize these phenomena with computational simulations using Zemax Optic Studio software. Sequence with PHYS 626, PHYS 627. Prereq: PHYS 627 with B- or better grade.

Classification and quantum numbers of elementary particles; elements of group theory, Lorentz group and spin; discrete and continuous symmetries; phenomenology of weak, electromagnetic, and strong interactions; quark model of hadron structure. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 633.

Classification and quantum numbers of elementary particles; elements of group theory, Lorentz group and spin; discrete and continuous symmetries; phenomenology of weak, electromagnetic, and strong interactions; quark model of hadron structure. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 661.

Canonical quantization, path integral formulation of quantum field theory, Feynman rules for perturbation theory, quantum electrodynamics, re normalization, gauge theory of the strong and electroweak interactions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 634.

Canonical quantization, path integral formulation of quantum field theory, Feynman rules for perturbation theory, quantum electrodynamics, re normalization, gauge theory of the strong and electroweak interactions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 665.
Crystallography; thermal, electrical, optical, and magnetic properties of solids; band theory; metals, semiconductors, and insulators; defects in solids. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 633.
Crystallography; thermal, electrical, optical, and magnetic properties of solids; band theory; metals, semiconductors, and insulators; defects in solids. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 671.

CourseID: PHYS 674. Theory of Condensed Matter. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Advanced topics include quantum and statistical description of many-particle systems, electronic structure, elementary excitation s in solids and fluids, critical phenomena, statics and dynamics of soft condensed matter. Topics and emphasis vary. Prereq: PHYS 673.

CourseID: PHYS 675. Theory of Condensed Matter. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Advanced topics include quantum and statistical description of many-particle systems, electronic structure, elementary excitation s in solids and fluids, critical phenomena, statics and dynamics of soft condensed matter. Topics and emphasis vary. Prereq: PHYS 674.

Introduction to the theory behind semiconductors. Elementary theory of inorganic solids; electronic structures and transport properties. Basic theory of devices including diodes, transistors, mosfets, and op to electronic devices. Offered only in summer. Sequence with PHYS 678M, PHYS 679M. Multi listed with CH 677M.

CourseID: PHYS 678M. Semiconductor Processing and Characterization Technology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to the techniques required to make semiconductors and test their properties. Solid-state and surface chemistry of inorganic semiconductors as it pertains to microelectronic devices. Offered only in summer. Sequence with PHYS 677M, PHYS 679M. Multi listed with CH 678M. Prereq: PHYS 677M.

CourseID: PHYS 679M. Device Processing and Characterization Laboratory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Students use theory and techniques learned to design, fabricate, and test a device that performs a specific function, with an emphasis on wafer processing and device realization. Offered only in summer. Sequence with PHYS 677M, PHYS 678M. Multi listed with CH 679M. Prereq: PHYS 678M.

CourseID: PHYS 684. Quantum Optics and Laser Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Nonlinear optical processes and quantum statistical properties of light produced by such processes, laser theory, wave mixing processes, optical Bloch equations, field quantization, photon statistics, cooperative emissions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 354 or equivalent.

CourseID: PHYS 685. Quantum Optics and Laser Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Nonlinear optical processes and quantum statistical properties of light produced by such processes, laser theory, wave mixing processes, optical Bloch equations, field quantization, photon statistics, cooperative emissions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 684; coreq PHYS 631.

CourseID: PHYS 686. Quantum Optics and Laser Physics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Nonlinear optical processes and quantum statistical properties of light produced by such processes, laser theory, wave mixing processes, optical Bloch equations, field quantization, photon statistics, cooperative emissions. Sequence. Prereq: PHYS 685; coreq: PHYS 632.

CourseID: PS 102. Thinking Like a Social Scientist. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Illustrates how the ways social scientists think—using quantitative, qualitative, and interpretive methods—help to sharpen thinking for many contexts and careers.

CourseID: PS 106. Power, Politics, and Inequality. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines power and politics through the lens of inequality, focusing on the constant struggle between the haves and the have-nots.

CourseID: PS 109. Politics, Science, and the Body. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: An interdisciplinary examination of the scientific and biological explanations of poverty and social inequality in the United States, historically and in the present day.

CourseID: PS 111. Introduction to Political Science. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Offers students the tools to think for themselves about politics: multiple ideological and analytical viewpoints on varying politic al arrangements around the world.
Theoretical introduction to American institutions, politic al doctrines, and ideology as these affect the course of politics and public policy in the United States.

CourseID: PS 208. Introduction to the Tradition of Political Theory. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Selected issues in politic al theory such as politic al obligation, rationality, diversity, and relativism. Covers contemporary and classical theories.

CourseID: PS 260. Public Policy and Democracy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Explores how American politic al ideals, interests, institutions, and history shape public policy, focusing on issues such as education, immigration, welfare, and civil liberties.
Overview of the United States legal system. Covers a range of socio legal writing and provides a context for the legal system under which the U.S. operates.

Explores the division among U.S. federal, state and municipal power through the lens of our nation’s most contentious and most critical politic al and policy debates. Examines how elected officials, judges, and activists influence fights over federalism.

CourseID: PS 304. Democracy, Dictators, and Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines key questions in politic al science like why some countries are rich while others are poor, why some countries are democratic and others are authoritarian, how these different politic al systems work, and which are best equipped to address ethno-nationalist conflict and economic development.

CourseID: PS 308. United States Political Thought. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Development of United States politic al thought from the Revolution through the 20th century. Includes writings of Jefferson, Paine, Madison, Tocqueville.

Ideology is a more-or-less coherent lens through which a person views the world in order to process information and direct action. The course examines how the world looks different for those holding liberal, conservative, communist, fascist, or anarchist world views.

Examines modern conceptions of democracy, citizenship, legality, virtue, equality, and politic al order, which grew out of ideas initially developed in ancient Greek city-states. Special attention given to ideas of active citizenship.

Examines contemporary conceptions of politics springing from European debates about the power of kings, law, and the people. Considers key textual moments in the process by which modern conceptions of democracy emerged.

Explores the distinct critiques of modernity offered by John Stuart Mill, Karl Marx, Friedrich Nietzsche, Michel Foucault, and Sigmund Freud. Concepts explored include liberalism, capitalism, power, morality, and the unconscious.

CourseID: PS 316. Black Lives Matter and American Democracy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Explores the ideological origins and contemporary politics of the Black Lives Matter movement. Modules include the demands of/on democracy, race and the criminal justice system, and the politics of protest.
Studies efforts by states to cooperate in an effort to avoid or resolve conflict in the realms of security, trade, human rights, and the environment.

CourseID: PS 326. United States Foreign Policy I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Basic concepts underlying the formulation and implementation of United States foreign policy; relationships between American society and foreign policy; the relationship of the U.S. to its inter national environment.

CourseID: PS 330. Governments and Politics in Latin America. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Social, politic al, and economic developments in Latin America; causes and consequences of revolutions, democratization, economic politics; examples from Mexico, Brazil, Chile, Argentina, Cuba, Guatemala, Venezuela. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: PS 337. The Politics of Development. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Presents alternative perspectives on key north-south issues: trade, aid, foreign investment, debt, and the environment. Includes such institutions as the International Monetary Fund, World Bank, and World Trade Organization.
Links between economics and politics in the inter national system. Basic concepts include power, dependence, inequality, imperialism, and development. EC 201, 202, or PS 205 recommended preparation.
Survey of the politics of the People's Republic of China. Emphasis on politic al sociology and group conflict: elites, ideology, social change, and organization.
Surveys major themes in contemporary Southeast Asian politics, including nation-state building, economic development, authoritarianism and democracy, and religious and ethnic politics.

CourseID: PS 346. Terrorism and Weapons Proliferation. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines causes and control of terrorism, especially preventing terrorist use of weapons of mass destruction; theories and policies of nonproliferation and arms control.

CourseID: PS 347. Political Power, Influence, and Control. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Survey of the use of the concept of power in the social sciences, stressing diverse theoretical perspectives and empirical studies of politic al institutions.

CourseID: PS 349. Mass Media and American Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: The role of the mass media in contemporary American politics; the effect of the media on such institutions as politic al parties, elections, and the presidency.
Examines the politic al relevance of films and their role as a medium for illustrating, defending, and challenging politic al ideas.

CourseID: PS 355. Oregon Government and Politics. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Current politic al issues in Oregon with particular attention to politic al races and ballot measures before the Oregon electorate as well as the state's major politic al institutions.

CourseID: PS 368. Gender in the Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines the role courts have played in framing and shaping policies where gender is a central feature with a focus on reproductive rights, pregnancy and abortion, domestic violence, rape, family issues, prostitution, and sexual harassment. Offered alternate years.
Study of Congress as an institution: congressional elections, the committee system, and the internal distribution of influence; relations with the president and the Supreme Court.

CourseID: PS 375. Race, Politics, and the Law. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines the development and transformation of race-based domination and resistance in the United States by examining the intersection of policy and law.
Politics viewed as strategic interactions among politicians, voters, and countries; focuses on how to model these interactions using tools of game theory.

CourseID: PS 380. Gender and Politics in Developing Countries. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines gender politics in the developing world and efforts to help women. Topics include female genital cutting, violence against women, economic development, microfinance, migration, trafficking. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: PS 386. United States Social Movements and Political Change. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Causes and consequences of American social movements. Considers theoretical perspectives. Topics may include agrarian populism, labor movement, civil rights movement, the women's movement, and identity politics.
Examination of the politic al and constitutional status of American Indian tribes in the United States, with some comparison to Canada. Focus on history, current policy, and potential futures.

Prepares students for writing the senior honors thesis in politic al science. Provides guidance in framing a suitable topic, conducting preliminary research, and writing a prospectus. Prereq: majors with honors standing.

CourseID: PS 433. Marxism and Radical Thought. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Surveys utopian socialist thought, anarchism, Marxism, and Leninism. Central themes include the nature of radical theory, the role of the state, human nature and the new society.

CourseID: PS 440. Causes and Prevention of War. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Surveys theories of causes of war; focuses on major theories of prevention; case studies from World War I, World War II, and other wars.

CourseID: PS 445. Methods for Politics and Policy Analysis I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to quantitative analysis, concepts and methods of empirical research, applied statistical data analysis in politic al science. Methods include descriptive statistics, bi variate correlation, and regression techniques.

CourseID: PS 446. Methods for Politics and Policy Analysis II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Survey of multivariate model building for politic al analysis. Multiple regression, discrete-variable techniques, recursive systems, and cross-level analysis. Application of these techniques to concrete politic al problems. Prereq: PS 445/545.

CourseID: PS 449. Racial Politics in the United States. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Considers how race has interacted with politic al development in the U.S. from the New Deal to the present.

CourseID: PS 460. Political Economy of East Asia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines the politic al economy of East Asia, with a focus on states, markets, and social classes during economic transformation. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: PS 465. LGBT Rights in the Courts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Analyzes the role of legal advocates and the courts in advancing and curtailing lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender rights with a focus on relationship recognition, parenting, employment, housing, military, education, and health care. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: PS 466. Civil Rights in Post-Warren Era. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Analyzes development in civil rights advocacy in the United States since the heyday of the Warren Court. Focuses primarily on developments in race, gender, disability, and sexuality. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: PS 467. The United States Presidency. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: An ambivalent view of the presidency as the key institution in the United States politic al system: source of great good but also of great harm.
Surveys how the U.S. Constitution works as a structure for government. Addresses how the federal courts interact within the U.S. system of government.

CourseID: PS 472. Matters of Life and Death. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines the right to life from politic al, legal, and philosophical perspectives. Considers abortion, capital punishment, assisted suicide, just-war theory, and animal rights.
How nations solve inter national environmental problems. Explores major problems, processes, and current debates. Evaluates existing treaties through case studies.

CourseID: PS 479. U.S. Interventions in Developing Nations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines theories of intervention: security, economic imperialism, humanitarian intervention, spreading democracy, domestic politics; over thirty-seven U.S. interventions since 1898 are surveyed.

CourseID: PS 484. United States Supreme Court. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: The Supreme Court as a politic al body; the judicial role in the context of the economic, politic al, social, and psychological factors that influence the court's decisions.

CourseID: PS 485. Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Overview of the role of rights in the United States legal system. Particular emphasis on the role of freedom and equality in a federal system.

CourseID: PS 491. Politics of Everyday Life. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines how we try to influence each other's behaviors in the course of everyday life. Readings from several disciplines.

CourseID: PS 495. United States Political Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines United States politic al-economic institutions from a comparative and historical perspective. Topics include rise and fall of mass production, labor and the law, and regional development.

CourseID: PS 533. Marxism and Radical Thought. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Surveys utopian socialist thought, anarchism, Marxism, and Leninism. Central themes include the nature of radical theory, the role of the state, human nature and the new society.

CourseID: PS 540. Causes and Prevention of War. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Surveys theories of causes of war; focuses on major theories of prevention; case studies from World War I, World War II, and other wars.

CourseID: PS 545. Methods for Politics and Policy Analysis I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to quantitative analysis, concepts and methods of empirical research, applied statistical data analysis in politic al science. Methods include descriptive statistics, bi variate correlation, and regression techniques.

CourseID: PS 546. Methods for Politics and Policy Analysis II. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Survey of multivariate model building for politic al analysis. Multiple regression, discrete-variable techniques, recursive systems, and cross-level analysis. Application of these techniques to concrete politic al problems.

CourseID: PS 549. Racial Politics in the United States. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Considers how race has interacted with politic al development in the U.S. from the New Deal to the present.

CourseID: PS 560. Political Economy of East Asia. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines the politic al economy of East Asia, with a focus on states, markets, and social classes during economic transformation.

CourseID: PS 565. LGBT Rights in the Courts. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Analyzes the role of legal advocates and the courts in advancing and curtailing lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender rights with a focus on relationship recognition, parenting, employment, housing, military, education, and health care. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: PS 566. Civil Rights in Post-Warren Era. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Analyzes development in civil rights advocacy in the United States since the heyday of the Warren Court. Focuses primarily on developments in race, gender, disability, and sexuality. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: PS 567. The United States Presidency. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: An ambivalent view of the presidency as the key institution in the United States politic al system: source of great good but also of great harm.
Surveys how the U.S. Constitution works as a structure for government. Addresses how the federal courts interact within the U.S. system of government.

CourseID: PS 572. Matters of Life and Death. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines the right to life from politic al, legal, and philosophical perspectives. Considers abortion, capital punishment, assisted suicide, just-war theory, and animal rights.
How nations solve inter national environmental problems. Explores major problems, processes, and current debates. Evaluates existing treaties through case studies.

CourseID: PS 579. U.S. Interventions in Developing Nations. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines theories of intervention: security, economic imperialism, humanitarian intervention, spreading democracy, domestic politics; over thirty-seven U.S. interventions since 1898 are surveyed.

CourseID: PS 584. United States Supreme Court. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: The Supreme Court as a politic al body; the judicial role in the context of the economic, politic al, social, and psychological factors that influence the court's decisions.

CourseID: PS 585. Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Overview of the role of rights in the United States legal system. Particular emphasis on the role of freedom and equality in a federal system.

CourseID: PS 595. United States Political Economy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines United States politic al-economic institutions from a comparative and historical perspective. Topics include rise and fall of mass production, labor and the law, and regional development.
Survey of rationales for qualitative methods in the social sciences and the main conceptual and practical issues raised in qualitative research. Offered alternate years.

One of three required seminars for PhD students planning to take a comprehensive examination in American politics. Explores how politic al science approaches the study of institutional contributions to politic al and policy developments.

CourseID: PS 619. United States Political Culture. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: In this course we examine the different ways that scholars study the relationship between politics and culture, and then focus on the United States as our case.

One of two required seminars for PhD students planning to take a comprehensive examination in inter national relations. Explores how politics and economics interact in shaping economic relations among states.

CourseID: PS 628. States and State-Society Relations. 5 Credits.
Descriptions: Examines how scholars have studied the state and its relationship to society. Students develop a comparative perspective of contentious politics ranging from peasant rebellions to revolutions to transnational social movements.
Doctoral-level survey of how politic al factors explain variations in national or regional trajectories of economic development, including industrialization, wealth, growth, and inequality.

CourseID: PSY 301. Scientific Thinking in Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Fundamentals in the empirical study of human behavior, including hypothesis formation, experiment design, behavioral data basics, and critical evaluation of scientific claims. Sequence with PSY 302, PSY 303. Students may not register for PSY 301 after completing PSY 303.

CourseID: PSY 302. Statistical Methods in Psychology. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Probability and statistics applied in psychological research. Topics include descriptive statistics, hypothesis testing, correlation, regression, and design of experiments. With laboratory. Sequence with PSY 301, PSY 303. Prereq: MATH 243 or one from MATH 241, MATH 246, MATH 251; PSY 301, WR 121; Pre- or coreq: PSY 201, 202.

CourseID: PSY 303. Research Methods in Psychology: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Practical experience designing, conducting, analyzing, and communicating original research about human behavior. Sequence with PSY 301, PSY 302. Repeatable once for a total of 8 credits when the topic changes. Prereq: PSY 201, PSY 202, PSY 301, PSY 302; one from WR 122, WR

Relationships between brain and endocrine activity and behavior. Topics include sensation, perception, sexual behavior, drug effects, eating, drinking, sleeping, dreaming, and learning. Prereq: PSY 201.

Processes underlying social perception and social interaction. Topics include aggression, the self-concept, stereotyping and prejudice, conformity, persuasion, attraction, and helping. Prereq: PSY 202.

Theory and methods for studying human traits, including personality tests and measures. Current research in personality. Studies of age, gender, culture, and relation to emotion and motivation. Prereq: PSY 202.

Major descriptive and theoretical approaches to etiological, developmental, and social factors in emotion and personality disorders. Includes assessment, diagnosis, treatment, and special topics. Prereq: PSY 202.

CourseID: PSY 348. Music and the Brain. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Explores the neural correlates of our perception of tonality, harmony, melody, and rhythm and how these relate to neurobiology, brain damage, and cognitive neuroscience.
Critical analysis of evidence for sex differences, gender roles, and the effect of gender on traditional issues in psychology. Topics include parenthood, violence, and sexual orientation.
Physiological and behavioral effects of psychoactive drugs such as alcohol, opiates, barbiturates, and ex c it ants. The psychology of use and overuse; therapies for correcting drug problems.

The nature of human sexuality; hormonal, instinctual, and learned factors in sexuality; psychosexual development; sexual orientation; frequency and significance of various types of sexual behavior; sexual inadequacy; sexual deviation.

Intermediate-level practical data analysis and interpretation. Topics include experimental design, analysis of variance, multiple regression, exploratory data analysis. Extensive computer use. Honors only. Prereq: PSY 303.

Introduction to topics of concern to both psychology and the law. Includes eyewitness identification, legal decision-making, criminal defenses, profiling, polygraph y, and mental-health law. Prereq: PSY 303.

Processes underlying learning and memory, including evolution. Topics range from simple forms of behavior change to the acquisition, retention, forgetting, and retrieval of symbolic information. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 304, PSY 305.
Motor and intellectual capacities; analysis of the flow of information within the nervous system; applications of performance principles to human-machine systems. Prereq: PSY 303, PSY 305.

Topics covered are color, size, shape, depth, distance, and movement. Examines the relationships between stimuli and perception, stimuli and the neural response, and the neural response and perception. Prereq: PSY 303, PSY 304.

Processes and structures underlying language use. Methods of studying language processing. Relationships between psycho linguistic data and observations from linguistics and neuro physiology. Prereq: PSY 303, PSY 305.

CourseID: PSY 445. Brain Mechanisms of Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Organization of the mammalian brain. Structure and function of the neuronal systems underlying vision, perception, motivation, coordinated movement, sleep-wakefulness, learning and memory, and affective disorders. Prereq: PSY 303, 304.
Integrative neural mechanisms of normal and abnormal processes in systems (e.g., selective attention, language, memory, object recognition, and emotion). Prereq: PSY 303, 304.
Relationships among the brain, endocrine systems, and behavior. Developmental effects of hormones on the brain, puberty, sexuality, aggression, stress. Prereq: PSY 303, PSY 304.
Topics in small-group dynamics, including decision-making, conflict, and changes over time in group structure and behavior. Prereq: PSY 303.
Psychological processes involved in judgment and decision-making. Normative theories of ideal behavior contrasted with descriptive analysis of actual behavior. Prereq: PSY 303.

Examines interdependence between mind and culture in substantive domains such as social cognition, motivation, emotion, and psychopathology. Cultural pluralism, collective identities, tolerance, and diversity considered. Prereq: PSY 303.
Adaptive human behavior; considers biological processes involved in emotions, how emotions interact with cognition, and social influences. Prereq: PSY 303.

Cognitive, neuro psychological, developmental, social, and clinical approaches to understanding trauma. Includes analysis of childhood trauma, sexual assault, domestic violence, terrorism, combat, and natural disasters. Prereq: PSY 303.

Adult intimacy and love relationships. Clinical-counseling approaches: assessment, couple and family therapies, and evaluation. Models of relationship functioning and the empirical study of interpersonal relationships. Prereq: PSY 303.

Intellectual development in children from infancy to adolescence with a focus on early childhood. Topics covered include perception, attention, memory, reasoning, conceptual structure, social cognition. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 305, PSY 308.

How children acquire language from the earliest speech sounds to full sentences. Topics include babbling, first words, word combinations, the relationship between cognition and language development. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 305, PSY 308.

Theoretical issues and empirical studies of social-emotional development. Topics may include attachment, temperament, moral development, family interaction, self-image, aggression, and sex-role development. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 306, PSY 307, PSY 308.

Mechanisms and processes that underlie and promote rapid changes in physical, cognitive, and linguistic capabilities, from birth to 24 months. Covers innovative methodologies and cultural attitudes toward infants. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 308, PSY 376.

Biological and environmental factors that shape normal and abnormal development. Analysis of how family functioning affects psychopathology and resilience in children and adolescents. Prereq: PSY 303; one course from PSY 308, PSY 309.
Intermediate-level practical data analysis and interpretation. Topics include experimental design, analysis of variance, multiple regression, exploratory data analysis. Extensive computer use.
Introduction to topics of concern to both psychology and the law. Includes eyewitness identification, legal decision-making, criminal defenses, profiling, polygraph y, and mental-health law.
Processes underlying learning and memory, including evolution. Topics range from simple forms of behavior change to the acquisition, retention, forgetting, and retrieval of symbolic information.
Motor and intellectual capacities; analysis of the flow of information within the nervous system; applications of performance principles to human-machine systems.

Topics covered are color, size, shape, depth, distance, and movement. Examines the relationships between stimuli and perception, stimuli and the neural response, and the neural response and perception.
Processes and structures underlying language use. Methods of studying language processing. Relationships between psycho linguistic data and observations from linguistics and neuro physiology.

CourseID: PSY 545. Brain Mechanisms of Behavior. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Organization of the mammalian brain. Structure and function of the neuronal systems underlying vision, perception, motivation, coordinated movement, sleep-wakefulness, learning and memory, and affective disorders.
Integrative neural mechanisms of normal and abnormal processes in systems (e.g., selective attention, language, memory, object recognition, and emotion).
Psychological processes involved in judgment and decision-making. Normative theories of ideal behavior contrasted with descriptive analysis of actual behavior.

Examines interdependence between mind and culture in substantive domains such as social cognition, motivation, emotion, and psychopathology. Cultural pluralism, collective identities, tolerance, and diversity considered.

Cognitive, neuro psychological, developmental, social, and clinical approaches to understanding trauma. Includes analysis of childhood trauma, sexual assault, domestic violence, terrorism, combat, and natural disasters.

Adult intimacy and love relationships. Clinical-counseling approaches: assessment, couple and family therapies, and evaluation. Models of relationship functioning and the empirical study of interpersonal relationships.

Intellectual development in children from infancy to adolescence with a focus on early childhood. Topics covered include perception, attention, memory, reasoning, conceptual structure, social cognition.
How children acquire language from the earliest speech sounds to full sentences. Topics include babbling, first words, word combinations, the relationship between cognition and language development.

Theoretical issues and empirical studies of social-emotional development. Topics may include attachment, temperament, moral development, family interaction, self-image, aggression, and sex-role development.

Mechanisms and processes that underlie and promote rapid changes in physical, cognitive, and linguistic capabilities, from birth to 24 months. Covers innovative methodologies and cultural attitudes toward infants.
Biological and environmental factors that shape normal and abnormal development. Analysis of how family functioning affects psychopathology and resilience in children and adolescents.
Introduction to probability, hypothesis testing, and analysis of variance with applications. Includes training in the statistical analysis of data by computer. With laboratory.
Multiple regression and advanced topics in analysis of variance. Includes training in the statistical analysis of data by computer. With laboratory. Prereq: PSY 611.
Multivariate techniques including MANOVA, factor analysis, principal components. Includes training in the statistical analysis of data by computer. With laboratory. Prereq: PSY 612.
Definition, measurement, and diagnosis of deviant behavior; includes critical reviews of research on the etiology, intervention, and outcome of major mental disorders. Prereq: major standing.

CourseID: INTL 423 Development and the Muslim World J 467 Issues in International Communication:
Descriptions: [Topic] (The Arab World and the Media) JDST 340 Israelis and Palestinians PS 399 Special Studies: [Topic] (Egypt; Politics of the Middle East) REL 102 World Religions: Near Eastern Traditions REL 233 Introduction to Islam REL 324–325 History of Eastern Christianity REL 335 Introduction to the Qur'an REL 432 Islamic Mysticism: [Topic] REL 435 Advanced Study of the Qur’an: [Topic] TA 472 Multicultural Theater: [Topic] (Arab
Development of Arabic speaking, reading, writing and comprehension; study of short literary and cultural materials. Sequence: ARB 202, 203. Prereq: ARB 103 or equivalent.

Provides third-year-level Arabic proficiency and substantially adds to the vocabulary base. Activates and augments grammar structures of modern spoken Arabic, colloquial Egyptian Arabic, and the study of Arabic culture. Sequence: ARB 302, 303. Prereq: ARB 203.

Provides third-year-level Arabic proficiency and substantially adds to the vocabulary base. Activates and augments grammar structures of modern spoken Arabic, colloquial Egyptian Arabic, and the study of Arabic culture. Sequence: ARB 301, 303. Prereq: ARB 301.

Provides third-year-level Arabic proficiency and substantially adds to the vocabulary base. Activates and augments grammar structures of modern spoken Arabic, colloquial Egyptian Arabic, and the study of Arabic culture. Sequence: ARB 301, 302. Prereq: ARB 302.
Improves students' abilities to work with classical Arabic texts; serves as a gateway to other classical Arabic text courses. Prereq: ARB 202 or equivalent.
Introduction to Arab cinema and culture through an examination of the development of cinema in Arabic-speaking countries. Offered alternate years.

CourseID: REL 101. World Religions: Asian Traditions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to related religious traditions of Asia, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Daoism, Confucianism and Shinto. Readings in sacred texts and scholar la ry literature. Lecture, discussion.

CourseID: REL 102. World Religions: Near Eastern Traditions. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to the Abrahamic religions of Judaism, Christianity, Islam and to related traditions such as the Zoroastrian, Manichaean, Mandean, Baha'i. Lecture, discussion.

CourseID: REL 222. Introduction to the Bible I. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Content and organization of the Hebrew scriptures (Old Testament); examination of scholarly methods and research tools used in biblical studies.
Islamic religious tradition, beginnings to present. Pre-Islamic Arabia, Prophet Muhammed, pillars of Islam, ethics and piety, Sunni-Shiite divide, reform and renewal movements.
Prehistoric roots of Chinese religion, Confucius and his followers, philosophical Taoism, Han Confucianism, religious Taoism, Chinese Buddhism, Neo-Confucianism, religion in China today.
Early Shinto and its developments, Japanese Buddhism, transformation of Taoism and Confucianism, medieval Shinto, religion in the Tokugawa period, Nationalistic Shinto, folk religion, new religions.
An introduction to the major religious traditions of the Indian subcontinent: Hinduism and Buddhism, and more briefly Sikhism and Jainism.
Women and their roles in Judaism; emphasis on early modern and contemporary eras. Texts read include historical, literary, and theoretical documents.

Course of Christian history in East and West; relations between spirituality, doctrine, and institutional forms. Covers the ancient period, from the Apostolic Fathers to the Islamic conquests (90–650).

Course of Christian history in East and West; relations between spirituality, doctrine, and institutional forms. Covers medieval Western Christianity, from the Germanic invasions to the Reformation (400–1500).

Course of Christian history in East and West; relations between spirituality, doctrine, and institutional forms. Covers modern Western Christianity, from the Reformation to the present (1500 to the present).

CourseID: REL 335. Introduction to the Qur'an. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: An introduction to the nature of the Qur'an and the various ways it has been interpreted throughout history by both Muslims and non-Muslims.

CourseID: REL 353. Dark Self, East and West. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Comparative examination of self hood in Eastern and Western religious thought and cultural contexts. Focus on dark side or problematic dimensions of Buddhist, Christian, Daoist, Jewish, and other thought.
The experiential or mystical dimensions of the three major Abrahamic faiths. Exploration of the original writings of men and women from each spiritual tradition.

CourseID: REL 357. War, Terrorism, and Religion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Offers an examination of the theme of war, terrorism, and religion, focusing on cases of religiously motivated acts of violence in the contemporary era.
Atheist critiques of religion, analyses of secularism from multiple disciplinary perspectives, and responses to atheism and secularism by modernist Christian, Muslim, and Buddhist writers.

CourseID: REL 411. Making Sense of Religion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: History of the study of religion, from the late 19th century to the present, as an expression of society, agent of oppression, psychological experience, symbolic system, and Western concept. Junior standing required.

Exploration of the Dead Sea Scrolls literature. Focus on either biblical texts and the development of the Hebrew Bible or non biblical texts and sectarian Judaism. Repeatable once when topic changes for a maximum of 8 credits.

Close reading of one or more books of the Judeo-Christian Bible in literary, historical, and cultural contexts; history of interpretation; and critical scholarship. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

Exploration of themes of sacrifice and martyrdom in ancient and medieval literatures of the Abrahamic traditions. Comparative approach to development of concepts within and across religious boundaries.

CourseID: REL 424. Early and Medieval Christian Heresy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Survey of various heretical beliefs from early medieval Christian history; examines alternative visions of Christian truth, and the formation from heterodoxy of orthodoxy.

CourseID: REL 426. Sex and Gender in Early Christianity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Study of how and why certain early Christians sought, successfully, to normalize certain interrelated cultural constructions of gender, the body, and sexuality.

Inner dimensions of Islamic piety and righteousness, from the Koranic and prophetic foundations to principal thinkers in the medieval Arabic and Persian Sufi traditions. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: REL 435. Advanced Study of the Qur’an: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Close reading of a section of the Qur’an in terms of its literary, historical, and cultural contexts, history of interpretation, and critical scholarship. Sequence with REL 335. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when topic changes.

CourseID: REL 440. Readings in Buddhist Scriptures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Readings in representative scriptures in English translation. Selection based on their import in development of Indian Buddhist philosophy and their impact on evolution of East Asian forms of Buddhism.
Medieval Japanese Buddhism of the 12th and 13th centuries. Examination of religious thought and cultural history including Zen and Pure Land.

CourseID: REL 511. Making Sense of Religion. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: History of the study of religion, from the late 19th century to the present, as an expression of society, agent of oppression, psychological experience, symbolic system, and Western concept.

Exploration of the Dead Sea Scrolls literature. Focus on either biblical texts and the development of the Hebrew Bible or non biblical texts and sectarian Judaism. Repeatable once when topic changes for a maximum of 8 credits.

Close reading of one or more books of the Judeo-Christian Bible in literary, historical, and cultural contexts; history of interpretation; and critical scholarship. Repeatable twice when topic changes for a maximum of 12 credits.

Exploration of themes of sacrifice and martyrdom in ancient and medieval literatures of the Abrahamic traditions. Comparative approach to development of concepts within and across religious boundaries.

CourseID: REL 524. Early and Medieval Christian Heresy. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Survey of various heretical beliefs from early medieval Christian history; examines alternative visions of Christian Truth, and the formation from heterodoxy of orthodoxy.

CourseID: REL 526. Sex and Gender in Early Christianity. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Study of how and why certain early Christians sought, successfully, to normalize certain interrelated cultural constructions of gender, the body, and sexuality.

Inner dimensions of Islamic piety and righteousness, from the Koranic and prophetic foundations to principal thinkers in the medieval Arabic and Persian Sufi traditions. Repeatable twice for a maximum of 12 credits.

CourseID: REL 535. Advanced Study of the Qur’an: [Topic]. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Close reading of a section of the Qur’an in terms of its literary, historical, and cultural contexts, history of interpretation, and critical scholarship. Repeatable once for a maximum of 8 credits when topic changes.

CourseID: REL 540. Readings in Buddhist Scriptures. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Readings in representative scriptures in English translation. Selection based on their import in development of Indian Buddhist philosophy and their impact on evolution of East Asian forms of Buddhism.
Medieval Japanese Buddhism of the 12th and 13th centuries. Examination of religious thought and cultural history including Zen and Pure Land.

Introduction to French stressing the development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills through a communicative approach. Sequence. Conducted in French. Prereq: FR 101.

Intensive study for experienced language learners; introduction to French culture. Cannot be combined with FR 101, 102, 103 for more than 15 credits of first-year French. Prereq: FR 111.

CourseID: FR 150. Cultural Legacies of France. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: French civilization in France and beyond. Possible topics are the Francophone world; pre modern, early modern, and modern France; French film, architecture, and painting. Conducted in English.

Development of reading, writing, and speaking skills; study of short literary and cultural texts; considerable attention paid to oral use of the language. Sequence. Prereq: first-year language competence.
Development of reading, writing, and speaking skills; study of short literary and cultural texts; considerable attention paid to oral use of the language. Sequence. Prereq: FR 201.

CourseID: FR 301. Culture et langage: la France con tempo raine. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Training in language and culture of modern France using newspapers, short stories, poetry and film. Vocabulary enrichment activities. Conducted in French. Prereq: FR 203.

CourseID: FR 302. Culture et langage: Le monde francophone con tempor a in. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Training in language and cultures of the French-speaking world using literary texts, websites, videos. Grammar review and vocabulary enrichment. Prereq: FR 203.

Repeatable. Practice in improving oral, comprehension, and listening skills in French. Communicative activities in class in addition to language laboratory work. Repeatable once for maximum of 4 credits. Prereq: FR 203 or equivalent.

CourseID: FR 312. French Survey: Francophone Literature. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to major authors and texts of the French-speaking world outside of France. Prereq: FR 301 or FR 302.

CourseID: FR 317. French Survey: Medieval and Renaissance. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to major themes and ideas in French literature from the medieval and Renaissance periods through the reading of representative texts. Prereq: FR 301 or FR 302.

CourseID: FR 318. French Survey: Baroque and Enlightenment. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Introduction to major themes and ideas in French literature from the 17th and 18th centuries through the reading of representative texts. Prereq: FR 301 or FR 302.

CourseID: FR 319. French Survey: 19th and 20th Centuries. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Representative literary works from the 19th and 20th centuries with attention to literary analysis and literary history. Prereq: FR 301 or FR 302.

CourseID: FR 320. Intensive French Grammar Review. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Promotes linguistic competency in French through intensive review and refinement of French grammar while introducing basic vocabulary and linguistic concepts. Prereq: FR 203.
Poems from the Middle Ages to the 20th century, literary movements, introduction to textual analysis and modern critical approaches. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.
Explores important aspects of French theater. Reading plays from different periods. Emphasizes formal aspects and critical reading. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.
Covers important aspects of French narrative. Reading texts from different periods. Emphasis on formal aspects and critical reading. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

CourseID: FR 361. French Cinema for Non majors. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: An introduction to the major movements of French cinema for non majors. No prior knowledge of film studies or French culture required. Taught in English.

Focuses on the differences between American culture and French and Francophone cultures. Addresses a sensitive issue exemplified by the attitude of the inter national movie industry. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

Repeatable. Recent topics include French Novel and World War II, Writers and Painters, Medieval is m, Francophone Caribbean, Gide and Sartre. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

CourseID: FR 416. Advanced Writing in French. 4 Credits.
Descriptions: Extended written production; writing for specific purposes and audiences. Advanced grammar review and composition; study of specialized vocabulary. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.
Offers an overview of translation theory and practice from English to French and French to English. Prereq: FR 301, FR 302.

Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 17th-century French literature. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

Intensive study of representative plays by Moliere, Racine, or Corneille with emphasis on modern criticism. Repeatable when topic changes for maximum of 16 credits. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 18th-century French literature. A recent topic is Being Modern in the 18th century. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 19th-century French literature. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

Changing topics concerning trends or particular authors representative of 20th-century French literature. Recent topics include African Identities, The French Novel in 2000, Postcolonial Africa. Repeatable when topic changes. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

Study of literary works representative of the Francophone world. Topics may include Francophone African Literature, Quebec Literature, Writing the Haitian Revolution. Repeatable five times for a maximum of 24 credits. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.

Developments in literature by women from areas such as Maghreb, the Caribbean, Sub-Saharan Africa, Quebec, the Indian Ocean, and Europe. Prereq: two survey courses from FR 312, FR 317, FR 318, or FR 319.
